message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Macular degeneration is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms, fundoscopic exam findings, and Amsler grid results. Choroidal melanoma would present with a mass lesion visible on fundoscopy. Open-angle glaucoma would not cause difficulty reading and would not be seen on fundoscopic exam or Amsler grid. Retinal detachment would present with sudden vision loss and would not have the progressive course described in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and findings on fundoscopic examination and Amsler grid suggest that the most likely diagnosis is macular degeneration. Choroidal melanoma would show a mass on fundoscopic examination, open-angle glaucoma would have characteristic optic nerve changes, and retinal detachment would present with sudden onset of visual changes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, fundoscopic examination, and Amsler grid findings suggest macular degeneration. Of the options, choroidal melanoma would present with visual field defects, open-angle glaucoma would present with optic nerve changes, and retinal detachment would present with sudden loss of vision. The early hyperfluorescence on fluorescein angiography also supports the diagnosis of macular degeneration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, fundoscopic examination findings, Amsler grid abnormalities, and early hyperfluorescence on fluorescein angiography suggest the most likely diagnosis is macular degeneration. Choroidal melanoma would be detected on ophthalmoscopy, and retinal detachment would present with sudden vision loss and floaters. Open-angle glaucoma would show optic nerve cupping on examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has progressive difficulty reading and a fundoscopic exam shows drusen and retinal elevation, indicative of macular degeneration. Choroidal melanoma would present with a different fundoscopic exam, while open-angle glaucoma and retinal detachment would not cause visual changes on the Amsler grid or early hyperfluorescence on fluorescein angiography.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest macular degeneration, as it is commonly associated with progressive difficulty reading and trouble recognizing fine details. The presence of drusen and retinal elevation also support this diagnosis. Choroidal melanoma would present with a mass on ophthalmologic examination, while open-angle glaucoma and retinal detachment would present with different symptoms on the Amsler grid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the fundoscopic exam suggest macular degeneration. The Amsler grid shows distortion in the central vision, which is commonly observed in patients with macular degeneration. The early hyperfluorescence seen on fluorescein angiography supports the diagnosis. Choroidal melanoma and retinal detachment are associated with different symptoms and physical exam findings. Open-angle glaucoma is not related to the patient’s symptoms or physical exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of progressive difficulty reading, trouble reading road signs, and fundoscopic examination shows localized retinal elevation and drusen, which are all suggestive of macular degeneration. The Amsler grid also shows an abnormality in the central vision, which is a characteristic of macular degeneration. The early hyperfluorescence seen on fluorescein angiography also supports this diagnosis. None of the other options are consistent with the patient’s presentation and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of progressive difficulty reading and avoidance of driving are classic for macular degeneration. The fundoscopic examination shows retinal elevation and drusen, both indicative of macular degeneration. The Amsler grid shows distortion of straight lines, which is also associated with macular degeneration. Fluorescein angiography shows early hyperfluorescence, which is consistent with macular degeneration. Choroidal melanoma, open-angle glaucoma, and retinal detachment would present with different symptoms and findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of progressive difficulty reading, avoiding driving due to trouble reading road signs, and localized retinal elevation and drusen on fundoscopic examination suggest macular degeneration. Fluorescein angiography showing early hyperfluorescence is also consistent with this diagnosis. Choroidal melanoma and retinal detachment typically present with sudden onset symptoms and may also have visual field defects or distortion. Open-angle glaucoma may have visual field loss but does not typically present with the described symptoms.
